title: RuPaul's Drag Race UK Scaredy Kat on sexuality, girlfriend and exit
text:
Scaredy Kat has left the competition Picture: BBC/ Leigh Keily / Matt Burlem)

RuPaul’s Drag Race UK has brought together drag from different regions and generations, with Scaredy Kat giving a very Gen Z twist on the art form.

And according to her, we should brace ourselves for the kids turning drag on its head.

Speaking to Metro.co.uk, Scaredy said: ‘I feel like our generation just gives less of a s*** about so many things. I mean, they care about some things very passionately, but other things, it’s like “it’s cool, just let it happen”. I think drag is definitely mixed with that.

‘Like Adore [Delano] – even though she’s a millenial, it’s very Gen Z-y, you know, buy £12 drag off Ebay, put on a wig and just have fun. I stopped wearing nails because they’re a f***ing nightmare, and they’re probably bad for the planet as well.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

Scaredy – the drag name of 20-year-old Sandy – most definitely showed a different side of drag on RuPaul’s Drag Race. For starters, the then-teenager had never performed in public before, and isn’t gay.

Scaredy and girlfriend Pussy are both drag queens (Picture: Nils Jorgensen/REX )

After shocking her fellow queens with this admission, Scaredy explained that she wasn’t comfortable with the labels bisexual and pansexual, saying: ‘I wouldn’t really call it bi. I just go out with anyone I fall in love with really. But honestly. My sexuality is my girlfriend. I wouldn’t want to be with anyone else.’

And Scaredy’s girlfriend – Bear, or Pussy Kat – is just as into drag as her boyfriend, with the pair working together on Scaredy’s post drag career.

Speaking after becoming the second queen to be eliminated from Drag Race UK, Scaredy said: ‘I’ve released a music video. We filmed the whole thing, it’s got animation in it, we did all of that, we edited it, we directed it, we came up with the set, we’ve done everything – because that’s what we do, we’re artists, and we do everything before.

‘We have an art exhibition explained. We want to take drag to the next level and take our art to the next level, and try and get to as many people as possible, because art nowadays is a bit s*** really, isn’t it? We want to change that and make it more fun and accessible. Going to galleries should be like going to the cinema.

Scaredy was the youngest queen of the series (Picture: BBC)

‘Every single decision I make, everything I do, it goes through her first, and the same with her. We do everything together, and I wouldn’t be here, I couldn’t do what I do, without her.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

Scaredy’s sexuality and relationship became a hot topic on the BBC Three show, and has dominated much of the reaction to the queen – and there has been good and bad.

‘I’ve had kids messaging saying “I didn’t know I could do drag because I’m bi”, which is nuts to me, or “I’ve got a girlfriend”, “I’m a girl, I didn’t know I could do drag, and you’ve made me realise that I can”,’ Scaredy told us. ‘I never even thought about that as being a thing.

To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

‘Then there’s been people saying, oh, he’s straight. There’s a whole conspiracy that Pussy is pushing me to do it and I’m actually a really macho guy. The hate for me is more controversy, which I’m all for – I’ll get straight stuck into that.’

Scaredy made it to the second week of Drag Race UK but failed to impress with her acting abilities, and was eliminated in favour of Blu Hydrangea after lip syncing for the very first time.

Advertisement

‘I’m happy with what I said and did, and I think I did well for a baby queen,’ the Wiltshire queen said. ‘I’m still a baby now but I’ve come a long way since I did the show, so it’s weird to look back.

‘I have this weird paradox of extreme anxiety and extreme desperation for attention. So I will just push through for the rush of it and fun of it. That comes across as confident apparently, which is nice, but really I’m screaming inside.’

RuPaul’s Drag Race UK continues on BBC Three at 8pm on Thursday.

description: RuPaul's Drag Race UK's latest eliminated queen Scaredy Kat talks girlfriend Pussy Kat, sexuality and why Gen Z is mixing up drag.
